respStmt.resp: XML encoding, hyperlinking and textual cleanup

availability.p: This text may be freely distributed, subject to the following restrictions:

list.item: You credit Perseus, as follows, whenever you use the document: Text provided by Perseus Digital Library, with funding from The U.S. Department of Education and The Max Planck Society.
You leave this availability statement intact.
You offer Perseus any modifications you make.

notesStmt.note: Initial XML cleanup by Alpheios Technical Services, LLC.
Major XML restructuring and text-correction by Winfried H. Leclaire (quranic-research.net)
Additional proofreading by Naveed Ul Islam (lanelexicon.com)

list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter h c
hu: the vowel of this pron. is sometimes, in a case of pause, transferred to the preceding letter: and this is always done in modern Arabic. ― -b2- ho subjoined in hunRaho, and the like: see OaboyaDu. ― -b3- The haA, termed tanobiyhN, is said by some to be used as an inceptive, without any meaning but inception. (See cA.) See kalimapu tanobiyhK in art. nbh: and see an ex. voce taA. When followed by a pronoun, as hw, &c., it is best rendered Lo. ― -b4- h of pausation: see remarks on a verse cited voce HiynN. ― -b5- bihaA, in HaTaOa bihaA, and many phrases syn. therewith, is app. for biQsotihi. See HaTaOa.

haMCa c
haMCa and haMCi: see art. hwO.

Q. Q. 3 AihobayRaxa c
Q. Q. 3. AihobayRaxa; (K;) and AihobayRaxato, aor. tahobayRixu; inf. n. UihobiyRaAxN; (TA;) He, (K,) and she, (TA,) walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (K, TA.)

habayRaxN c
habayRaxN, of the measure faEayRalN, (S,) A boy, or young man: and habayRaxapN a girl, or damsel: both in the dial. of Himyer. (L.) ― -b2- Also, the former, A soft boy, or young man: (K:) or the former and latter, respectively, a soft, thin-skinned, and plump, boy or young man, (S,) and girl or damsel: (S, K:) or a plump and goodly young man, and woman: (L:) or the latter, a tall and great woman: (JK:) [and hence, app., applied as an epithet, in the sense of long and large, to a woman's train, in the following verse, quoted by Az,]
jarRato Ealayohi AlrRiyHu cayolFA OanobaxaA
jarRa AlEaruwsi cayolahaA QlohabayRaxaA
(L.) [The wind dragged over it a train of dusky colour, and abounding with dust, like as the bride drags her long and large train.] ― -b3- Also, the latter, A damsel suckling, or that suckles. (M, K.) ― -b4- Also, the former, A stupid, and flabby, or flaccid, man. (K.) ― -b5- Also, a man in whom is no good. (K.) ― -b6- Also, A great valley. (K) ― -b7- And A large river. (K.)

hubaEN c
hubaEN, applied to a young camel: a young camel brought forth in the end of the breedingtime. (K, voce rubaEN, q. v.) See bulaEN.

1 habilato c
1. habilato, inf. n. habalN: see Eamila.

8 Aihotabala c
8. Aihotabala: see 5 in art. Hfw. ― -b2- I. q. taHayRana. (TA.)

hayobaliIRN c
hayobaliIRN A Christian monk: see OabiylN.

mahobilN c
mahobilN The place of gestation: see a verse cited voce maHobalN.

1 habAa AlrRamaAdu c
1. habAa AlrRamaAdu, (JK, TA,) aor. yahobuw, (TA,) The ashes became mixed with dust, and extinguished: (JK, TA:) and habAa Aljamoru. (M, art. rmd.)

hubapN c
hubapN: see OahobapN.

habowapN c
habowapN Dust rising, or spreading, in the sky like smoke. (JK.)

habaMCN c
habaMCN The motes that are seen in the rays of the sun: (TA:) see an ex. voce guvaMCN.

1 htk c
1. htk He rent open. (K, S.) ― -b2- htk AllReh sitorahu God dishonour him: see sitorN.

hatRaAkN c
hatRaAkN One who rends frequently tents and the like: see baAbN.

havaArahu c
havaArahu, for OanaArahu: see vwr.

5 tahajRaEa c
5. tahajRaEa He slept. (1001 Nights, ii. 321.)

hajoEapN c
hajoEapN (assumed tropical:) The setting of a star. (Sgh in TA, art. XrT.) See XaraTN. ― -b2- A light sleep in the first part of the night. (S.)

hawojalN c
hawojalN, of a ship or boat, is smaller than the Oanojar. (O, TA, voce maEaAbiyru.) ― -b2- See De Sacy, Chrest. Arab., ii. 359.

hajuwlN c
hajuwlN A fornicatress, or an adulteress: pl. hajaAYilu. (JK.)

1 hajamu Ealayohi c
1. hajamu Ealayohi He came upon him suddenly, or at unawares, (Mgh, Msb, K,) or came in to him without permission, (K,) or without asking permission: (Mgh:) he invaded, assaulted, assailed, attacked, attempted, or ventured upon, him or it: he pounced upon him or it.

hajomapN c
hajomapN, or, accord. to Kz, haziyEN, The third of the five divisions of the night. (TA.) See xudorapN, and yaEofuwrN. ― -b2- As applied to camels, see EaAYiDN and ziyAadapN.

entry.key: nakaHa fiI baniI fulAanK wahajRana OawolaAdahumo

superEntry.entry:
1 nakaHa fiI baniI fulAanK wahajRana OawolaAdahumo c
1. nakaHa fiI baniI fulAanK wahajRana OawolaAdahumo [He married among the sons of such a one, and made their children to be base-born, or ignoble]. (TA in art. bgl.)

hujonapN c
hujonapN [Meanness of race, in a horse]. (K, voce UiEorAabN.)

hajiynN c
hajiynN One whose father is free, or an Arab, and whose mother is a slave. (S, K.) ― -b2- A horse [half-blooded] got by a stallion of generous race out of a mare not of such race: (S:) or got
by an Arabian stallion out of a mare not of Arabian birth: (Msb:) or not of generous birth; a jade. (K.)

haAjinN c
haAjinN A girl not arrived at puberty, or a beast not yet fit to be covered: see an ex. voce jalRa.

1 hajaAhu c
1. hajaAhu He censured, dispraised, reviled, or satirized him, (S, Msb, K,) in verse. (Msb, K) ― -b2- maA hajawotu minohu XayoYFA: see 1 in art. Hjw.

3 haAjaAhu c
3. haAjaAhu, inf. n. muhaAjaApN, He contended with him in satirizing. See 4 in art. fHm.

OumojuwRapN c
OumojuwRapN, Dispraise, is like OusobuwbapN, contr. of OumoduwHapN.

10 Aisotahodafa c
10. Aisotahodafa He became a hadaf, or butt. (Har, p. 65.) See ratiymapN.

hadafN c
hadafN A high or lofty building: see SadafN.

1 hadala c
1. hadala He uttered a cry: see hadara, in two places.

5 tahadRala c
5. tahadRala It hung down; [it dangled;] said of a branch of a tree, (S, TA,) and of fruit; it hung loosely; said of the former. (TA.)

miXofarN Oahodalu c
miXofarN Oahodalu [A camel's lip] flaccid, or pendulous. (K, TA.)

1 hadama c
1. hadama He threw down, or pulled down, a building; (Msb;) pulled it to pieces; demolished it; destroyed it: (K:) [the last two explanations are the most correct, as is shown by the phrase] naqaDa AlbinaMCa mino Eayori hadomi [He took to pieces the building without demolishing, or destroying]: (S, A, Msb, K, * in art. qwD:) he ruined [a building, &c.]; reduced [it] to ruin. (Ham, p. 31.)

6 tahaAdamati AlHiyTaAnu c
6. tahaAdamati AlHiyTaAnu [The walls fell to ruin by degrees]. (S, in art. dEw.)

7 Ainohadama c
7. Ainohadama It became thrown down, pulled down, pulled to pieces, demolished, or destroyed: and it fell in ruins, or to pieces; or became a ruin. ― -b2- Ainohadama AlHaAYiTu mino makaAnihi mino gayori hadomN [The wall fell in ruins, or to pieces, from its place, without being pulled to pieces]. (Lth, in TA, art. qyD.)

AldRamu AldRamu waAlhadoamu Alhadoamu c
AldRamu AldRamu waAlhadoamu Alhadoamu: see damo.

hadamN c
hadamN Earth that is dug from a pit or well: see HafarN.

hidamolapN c
hidamolapN Food and drink: see fiToHalN.

hudonapN EalaI daxonK c
hudonapN EalaI daxonK An illusory truce: see duxaAnN.

1 hadaAhu c
1. hadaAhu He directed him, or guided him, to the way; (K, * TA;) directed him aright; or caused him to take, or follow, a right way or course or direction. (K, TA.) See 8. ― -b2- hadaI AlEaruwsa He sent [or conducted] the bride (MA, KL) to her husband, (MA,) or to the house of her husband: (KL;) i. q. zafRahaA, (K in art. zf,) and so OahodaAhaA↓. (Msb in that art.) ― -b3- yahodiI meaning yuWadRiI: see an ex. in a verse cited voce TabaEN.

4 OahodaIa
4: see 1.

6 tahaAdanaA c
6. tahaAdanaA They (two parties who had been at war) made a truce, each with the other. (T, art. nbc.)

8 AihotadaI c
8. AihotadaI He became rightly directed; followed a right direction; (K;) went aright; as also hadaI↓. (S.) ― -b2- He guided himself. ― -b3- He went a right way: went aright. ― -b4- laA yahotadiI UilaI jihapK He cannot go aright: or knows not the way that he would pursue; or knows not in what direction to go: sometimes said of a drunken man. ― -b5- laA yahotadiI liOamorihi means He does not, or cannot, find the way to accomplish, or perform, his affair. ― -b6- AihotadaI He found, (MA,) or took (KL,) the right way or road. (MA, KL.) ― -b7- daAhiyapu lAa yuhotadaI lahaA, by which daAhiyapu Algabari is expl. in the S and O, means laA yuhotadaI llRanRajaMCi minohaA, by which the same phrase is expl. in the JK: or it may be well rendered A calamity in relation to which one knows not the right course to pursue. ― -b8- AihotadaI also signifies He continued to be rightly directed, or to follow a right dirertion: and he sought to be rightly directed, or to follow a right direction. (TA.) ― -b9- AihadRaI and AihidRiI, for AihotadaI; like AiEacRara and AiEicRira, for AiEotacara.

hadoIN c
hadoIN A way, course, method, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or proceeding, or the like; (Msb, K;) as also hidoyapN↓ and hadoyapN↓: (K:) or to the second and third: and the first is pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of the last: (S:) and a god way, &c.: and calm, or placid, deportment; or calmness, or placidity, of deportment: (TA:) see also dalN. ― -b2- hadoIN [Conduct, mode of life; manners]. ＝ -A2- See hadiIRN.

huwa EalaI hudFI c
huwa EalaI hudFI He is following, or he follows, a right direction. ― -b2- AlhudaI The Kur-án. (Bd, Jel in lxxii. 13, &c.)

hidoyapN c
hidoyapN and hadoyapN: see hadoyN.

hadiyRapN c
hadiyRapN [n. un. of hadiIRN] A present; i. e. a thing sent to another in token of courtesy or honour: (Msb;) such as is termed TariyfN and laTafN. (JK.) ― -b2- hadoIN↓ and hadiIRN [coll. gen. ns.] What one brings as an offering to Mekkeh, (K,) or to the Kaabeh, (Beyd, v. 2,) or to the Haram, (S, Mgh,) consisting of camels (Lth, S, Mgh, Msb) or other beasts, (Lth,) namely kine or sheep or goats, (Mgh,) to be sacrificed, (TA,) and of goods or commodities: (Lth:) n. un. with p. (S, &c.) ― -b3- Also, Camels, absolutely. (TA.) ― -b4- hadiIRN also One who is entitled to respect, or honour, or protection: so in a verse cited voce AisotabaMCa. (ISk in T in art. bwO.)

haAdK c
haAdK: see an ex. of its pl. hawaAdiI meaning Necks of horses, voce taAlK. ― -b2- haAdiyapN The fore part of the neck of a horse. (K in art. slf.) ― -b3- Oaxaca haAdiIa AlrRaHaI fajaEala yudiyruhaA [He took the handle of the mill, and begun to turn it]. (K, art. xbz.)

OahodaI mino duEayomiySi AlrRamoli c
OahodaI mino duEayomiySi AlrRamoli More expert, &c.: see art. dEmS.

AlmahodiIRu c
AlmahodiIRu, meaning The directed by God to the truth, is a proper name, and the name of him of whose coming at the end of time the happy tidings have been announced. (TA.) [It is always so pronounced by the Arabs in the present day: not AlmuhodiI.]

1 hacRa bisaloHihi c
1. hacRa bisaloHihi He ejected his excrement. (TA, art. tr.)

1 hacaI c
1. hacaI He talked nonsense; he raved, or talked irrationally, foolishly, or deliriously; (JK, K;) by reason of disease or some other cause. (K.) ― -b2- hacaIbihi He talked irrationally, &c., with him. (TA.) ― -b3- And He mentioned him, or it, in his irrational, &c., talk. (TA.)

3 gaEada yuhaAciIOaSoHaAbahu c
3. gaEada yuhaAciIOaSoHaAbahu [He sat talking irrationally, &c., with his companions]. (TA.) ― -b2- samiEotuhumo yatahaAcuwna [I heard them talking together irrationally, &c.] (TA.)

XaraAbN haAcK c
XaraAbN haAcK (tropical:) [Beverage causing delirious, or irrational, talk.] (TA.)

1 harRa c
1. harRa, inf. n. hirRN, He drove sheep or goats:
(IAar, in S, K, voce bir:) or he called them. (Yoo, in TA, ibid.)

hirojaAlN c
hirojaAlN, pl. haraAjyl, A tall, long-bodied, or bulky, she-camel: (TA:) see hirojaAb.

haraAHa c
haraAHa: see OaraAHa.

harAasN c
harAasN A certain thorny or prickly tree, (S, K, TA,) the thorns or prickles of which are like the Hasak, (TA,) and its fruit is like the nabiq: n. un. with p. (K, TA.) See quTobN.

hiroXafRapN c
hiroXafRapN A piece of rag with which water is dried up from the ground. (TA, art. jf.) ― -b2- See hiroXabRapN.

hiroTaAlN c
hiroTaAlN A large long-bodied man. (Az, in TA, voce hirodabRapN.)

1 hariqo EalaI xamorika c
1. hariqo EalaI xamorika [Pour water upon thy wine; i. e.,] quiet thine anger. (T.) See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 875; also the same, ii. 877. ― -b2- hariqo EanRaA mino ruwbapi AllRayoli: see ruwbapN.

4 Oahoriqo Eanoka mina AlZRahiyrapi c
4. Oahoriqo Eanoka mina AlZRahiyrapi, i. q. Oaborido, q. v. (IAar, in TA, art. fyH.) See 4 in art. rwq. ― -b2- haraAqahu and OahorAaqahu and haraqahu↓, aor.
haraqa
, inf. n. haroqN, He poured it out, or forth: see 4 in art. rwq. ― -b3- hariyquwA Eanokumo OawRala AllRayoli, (in the K, erroneously, Ealayokumo,) Alight ye in the first of the night: (TA:) or disburden yourselves (OanoziluwA Enkm): or relieve, or rest, yourselves; which seems to be generally meant by hryqwA Enkm.

hiraAqapN c
hiraAqapN and UihoraAfapN The seminal fluid of a man: see UiraAqapN, in art. rwq.

Q. Q. 1 harowala c
Q. Q. 1. harowala He walked quickly: (Msb:) [he went a kind of trotting pace between a walk and a run; see ramala;) harowalapN is not so quick as xababN [an amble]; (Msb;) and is between maXoIN [a walk] and EadowN [a run]: (S, Msb, K:) it is a kind of EadowN: (S:) or quicker than EanaqN: or a quick walk. (K.)

1 harima c
1. harima He became extremely aged; (K;) old and infirm; (Msb;) decrepit; or a weak old man.

harimN c
harimN The mind: see 6 in art. rq.

AlkurRu AlhaAruwniIRu c
AlkurRu AlhaAruwniIRu: see kurRN.

hrnSAnp c
The hrnSAnp, (K,) i. e. hironiSaAnap, (TA,) or hirinoSaAnap, (so in the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K,) with kesr, (K,) and the r quiescent, and with kesr to the n, (TA,) is A certain worm, (K,) accord. to IAar; said by others to be (TA) what is called the surofap [which is very variously described]. (K, TA.) See duxolulN.

huroIN c
huroIN A granary: see niborN.

hazawRarN c
hazawRarN A strong boy or young man: and a weak old man: as also HazawRarN: pl. hazAawirapN. (Abu-t-Teiyib, in TA, art. Hzr.)

haziyEN c
haziyEN: see hajomapN.

1 hazolN c
1. hazolN is contr. of jidRN. (S, Mgh, K.) You say, hazala, aor.
hazila
, inf. n. hazolN; (S, Msb, K;) and hazila, aor.
hazala
, (K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and haAzala↓; (K;) He jested, or joked; (Msb;) or was not serious, or in earnest; (TA;) fiI kalAamihi in his speech; (Msb, TA;) and fiI AlOamori in the affair. (TA.)

3 haAzala c
3. haAzala He jested, or joked. (K.) See 1.

huzAalN c
huzAalN Leanness, meagreness, emaciation: contr. of fatness. (S, K.)

hazolaI c
hazolaI, pl. of haziylN Lean, meagre, emaciated. (K, voce xaXabN.)

mahozuwlN c
mahozuwlN: see two exs. in a verse cited voce EiroDN.

7 Ainohazama c
7. Ainohazama It (an army) was routed, discomfited, defeated, or put to flight. (K, &c.) See HaASa, in art. HyS; and AinoHaAza, in art. Hwz; from both of which it is distinguished.

hazomapN c
hazomapN The [purring, or] sound of the throat of a cat. (TA.) ― -b2- The pit between the two collar-bones. (TA, art. trb.) ― -b3- [The pit above a horse's eye.] (K, voce waqobN.) See also xunoEubapN, and qalotapN: and see EuqomN, where it seems to mean a stricture: it generally and properly signifies a depression, or dint: or a pit, or small hollow, resembling a dint: see also gayobN.

mahozuwmu AlSRadori c
mahozuwmu AlSRadori Depressed of breast, i. e., apparently, illiberal, niggardly: see HawoDN.

1 haXamahu c
1. haXamahu He crushed it.

2 haXRamahu c
2. haXRamahu, inf. n. tahoXiymN, He broke it [much, or so crushed it]; (TA;) namely, a dry thing, and anything hollow, such as the head, and the like. (TA in art. Xdx.)

5 tahaXRama c
5. tahaXRama It (a plant, or herbage,) became haXiym, i. e. dry, and broken in pieces.

haXiymN c
haXiymN A plant that is dry, and breaks, or is broken, in pieces. (S, Msb, K.)

haAXimapN c
haAXimapN A wound in the head which breaks the bone: see XajRapN.

AlkurRu AlhaAXimiIRu c
AlkurRu AlhaAXimiIRu: see kurRN.

1 hDamahu c and AihotaDamahu
1. hDamahu AihotaDamahu: see taxawRafahu. ― -b2- haDama lahu mino maAlihi: see xaDama.

5 tahaDRama
5: see 7.

7 AinohaDama c
7. AinohaDama It (a thing) melted, or dissolved, after being congealed. (JK.) ― -b2- AinohaDamati AlvRamarapu, and tahaDRamat↓, The fruit broke; or became broken, or crushed; syn. taXadRaxato; (TA;) and became mellow, so as to be easy of digestion. See also bawoEN ― -b3- AinohaDama, said of food, (MA), It was, or became, digestible, or easy of digestion. (MA, KL.) ― -b4- AinohDaAmN of the zawor [app. Depression]. (K in art. jnf. [There coupled with duxuwlN.]) See also SaqalN.

8 UihotaDama
8: see 1. ― -b2- AihotaDama AlXRajaza mino OaEalAahu (K voce XaEaba) He cropped the tops of the shrubs: see XaEaba.

haDamN c
haDamN Contraction of the sides, (S, K,) and lankness of the belly, and smallness of the flank: (K:) in a horse it is a fault. (S.)

haDuwmN c
haDuwmN: see haADuwmN.

haADuwmN c
haADuwmN Any medicine [or other thing (see HaATuwmN)] that is a digestive of food; as also haDuwmN↓; (K;) i. q. jawaAriXN. (S.)

1 haTala c
1. haTala It (water) poured: see its inf. n. voce sakobN.

hifRN c
hifRN Certain small fish, which are dried: see sumayokaMCu.

1 hfA c
1. hfA, said of the heart, It fluttered, or palpitated; and, as Z says, was flurried by reason of grief, or of beating. (TA.) See 1, in art. fhw.

hafowapN c
hafowapN A slip, lapse, fault, or fall into wrongdoing; pl. hafawaAtN. (TA.)

qarabN haqohaAqN c
qarabN haqohaAqN: see HaqoHaAqN.

hiqowarRN c
hiqowarRN A large, long-bodied man. (Az, in TA, voce hirodabRapN.)

AlhaqoEapu c
AlhaqoEapu Three small stars [ λ, φ 1, and φ 2, of Orion,] forming the points of a triangle, in the head of AljuwozAaCu The 5th Mansion of the Moon. (El-Kazweenee.) [This is accord. to those who make nawoCN to signify the “ auroral setting: ” accord. to those who make it to signify the “ auroral rising, ” these stars compose AlhanoEapu, q. v.; and AlhafoEapu seems to consist of o 1 and o 2 of Orion.]

1 hakRa c
1. hakRa: see sakRa.

haAkRN c
haAkRN: see faAkRN.

hakRaAkN c
hakRaAkN: see fakRaAkN.

4 OaholalonaA hilaAla Xahori kacaA c
4. OaholalonaA hilaAla Xahori kacaA: see salaxa.

10 AisotahalRa c
10. AisotahalRa: see a verse cited at the close of the first paragraph of art. DHk. ― -b2- See also a verse cited voce OafovaOa. ― -b3- See musotahalRN.

halo c
halo may be originally halow or haloI or halR: (Akh, in S, voce bl:) see balo. ― -b2- halo followed by UilaI: see the latter. ― -b3- HaIR hala: see HI. ― -b4- halRaA: see HaDRapN and Eano, latter part, and lawolaA, and OalRaA.

halRapN c
halRapN: see balRapN.

AlhilAalu c
AlhilAalu The new moon; or the moon when it is termed hilAal: it may be explained as meaning, generally, the moon when near the sun, or moon a little after or before the change. ― -b2- See samaA.

musotahalRu AlXRahori c
musotahalRu AlXRahori The first night of the lunar month. (Msb.)

yawomN hilRawofN c
yawomN hilRawofN: see OaHaSRu.

1 halaka c
1. halaka, inf. n. halaAkN &c., (S, K, &c.,) He, or it, perished, came to nought, came to an end, passed away, was not, was no more, or became non-existent or annihilated: (KL, PS in explanation of halAakN, &c.:) or fell: or became in a bad, or corrupt, state; became corrupted, vitiated, marred, or spoiled: or went away, no one knew whither: (Mgh in explanation of halAakN:) he died. (K.) ― -b2- halakato OaroDuhu His land had its herbage dried up by drought: see jariba.

2 waAdiI tuhulRika c
2. waAdiI tuhulRika I. q. tuDulRil

4 Oaholakahu c
4. Oaholakahu He destroyed, made an end of, or caused to perish or come to an end, made away, did away with, or brought to nought, him, or it; took away his life.

6 tahaAlaka gamRFA c
6. tahaAlaka gamRFA [app. He perished gradually by reason of grief.] (A, art. sws: see 1 in that art.) ― -b2- tahaAlaka Ealayohi He was vehemently eager for it. (TA.) ― -b3- tahaAlaka fiyhi He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, in it, namely in running; as also Aihotalaka↓. (TA.) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, and hastened, in it, namely an affair; as also Asthlk fyh↓. (TA.) ― -b4- tahaAlakato said of a she-camel, i. q. EaXiqato [She vehemently desired the stallion]. (AA, TA in art. EXq.)

8 Uihotalaka
8: see 6.

10 Aisotaholaka c
10. Aisotaholaka properly signifies He sought, or courted, destruction; like AisotamaAta: see musotamiyta: and see an ex. voce XaroXarapN. ― -b2- Aisotaholaka fiI kacaA He (a man) distressed, troubled, or fatigued, himself in, or respecting, such a thing. (TA.) See also 6.

halakapN c
halakapN The drying up of the plants, or herbage. (AHn, TA.) See halAakN.

halAakN c
halAakN [Perdition; destruction; a state of perdition or destruction: a lost state;] death. (K.) ― -b2- halAakN and halakapN↓ are syn. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b3- Airotabaka fiI AinohalakaAti He stuck fast in cases of perdition: see art. rbk.

haAlikN c
haAlikN Dead; or dying. (Bd, Jel in xii. 85) ― -b2- haAlikN sometimes means Subject to perish; as in the Kur, xxviii. last verse.

maholukN c
maholukN: see OaluwkN.

maholikN c
maholikN Death: see a verse cited voce sahuwN.

maholaikapN c
maholaikapN A cause of perdition, or of death. (TA in art. bxl.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A place of perdition or death: and a desert: (KL:) or a [desert, or such as is termed] mafaAzap; (S, K, TA;) because persons perish therein; (Z, TA;) or because it urges [or leads] to perdition. (TA.) See jaAdRapN.

huwa musotaholikN UilaI kacaA c
huwa musotaholikN UilaI kacaA i. q. musotamiytN [q. v.]. (TA, art. mwt, from the A.) ― -b2- musotaholiku Alwirodi A road that destroys him who seeks water, by reason of its far extent. (O.)

halumRa c
halumRa i. q. naEaAla Come. (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- It is intrans.; as in halumRa UilayonaA Come to us. And tran also; as in halumRa XuhadaMCa kumo Cause your witnesses to come; bring your witnesses. (Msb.) ― -b3- halumRa jarRFA At thine ease: see 1 in art. jr.

1 hamRa c
1. hamRa He purposed, or intended, a thing. hamRN denotes more than UiraAdapN, and less than EazomN. (Kull, p. 382.) ― -b2- laA mahamRapa walaA makaAdapa: see art. kwd. ― -b3- hamRa biAlXRaIoCi [He meditated, proposed to himself, purposed, or intended, to do the thing:] he desired to do the thing, (S, Msb,) without doing it; (Msb;) he endeavoured to do the thing. (S.) ― -b4- hamRa biAlOamori He intended the affair. or purposed it; or he desired it. (Mgh.) ― -b5- hamRa bihi fiI nafosihi [aor.
hamuma
] He intended it, meant it, desired it. or determined upon it, in his mind. (TA.) See also a verse cited voce rutamN. ― -b6- hm biAlbakaMCi [He was about, or ready, to weep; like OaraAda AlbukaMCa, and tahayRaOa lilbukaMCi q. v.]. (A, art. jhX, &c.) ― -b7- hamRa bAlsRuquwT [It threatened to fall], said of a
wall. (S, in art. whI, &c.) ― -b8- hamRahu and OahamRahu↓ It disquieted him; (Msb;) caused him care, or anxiety. ― -b9- laA yuhimRuhu UilRaA baTonuhu [Nothing causes him care, or anxiety, but his belly]. (S in art. bTn.)

4 OahamRatu c
4. OahamRatu It rendered him anxious; (MA;) disquieted him, and grieved him. (Mgh.) See EanaAhu.

7 AinhmRa c
7. AinhmRa: see a verse cited in art. b, p. 144.

8 AihotamRa biAlOamori c
8. AihotamRa biAlOamori He was grieved, and disquieted, by the affair, or case: (TA:) you say AihotamRa lahu biOamorihi he was grieved for him by his affair, or case. (S.) [He was, or became, anxious, disquieted, or grieved, by it.] ― -b2- He minded, or attended to, the affair: (MA:) undertook, or superintended, or managed, the affair. (Msb.) See EuniIa, in art. EnI. ― -b3- AihotamRa lahu He cared for, minded, or regarded, him, or it. (Har, p. 94.) ― -b4- AihotamRa balada kacaA i. q. AiEotasRahu. (TA in art. Es.)

hama c
hama for hamaA for OamaA before an oath: see the last.

hamRN c
hamRN and himRapN↓ Purpose, or intention; syn. OawRalu AlEazomi and OawRalu AlEaziymapi. (Msb.) See Har, p. 345, and a verse cited voce TalRaAE. ― -b2- Also the ↓latter, Strong determination or resolution. (Msb.) ― -b3- hamRN An object, or a thing intended or meant or desired or determined upon, in the mind. (K, * TA.) See an ex. voce HamRN and samRN: you say, hamRuhu kacaA His object is such a thing. ― -b4- hamRN [Anxiety; or disquietude, or trouble, of mind; solicitude; care: or grief, or sorrow:] distress, or disquietude, affecting the heart or mind, by reason of some harm, or annoyance, that is expected to happen; differing from gamRN, which signifies “ distress, or disquietude, affecting the heart or mind, by reason of what has happened: ” or both, as some say, signify the same [namely distress, or disquietude, of mind]: the difference is asserted by 'Iyád and others. (TA in art. gm.) ― -b5- hamRuhu baTonuhu [His object of care, or of anxiety, is his belly]. (K in art. bTn.) And laA hamRa lahu UilRaA baTonuhu [He has no object of care, or of anxiety, but his belly]. (TA in that art.) ― -b6- hamRaka maA hamRaka means hamRaka maA EanaAka: and hamRaka also signifies AcAbk. (JK.) See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 880.

himRN c
himRN A decrepit, old, and weak, or extremely aged. man. (S, Msb, K.)

hamRapN c
hamRapN: see himRapN.

himRapN c
himRapN A thing that one meditates, purposes, or intends to do; or that one desires to do; or endeavours to do; a purpose; an intention; or an object of desire, or of endeavour; as also hamRapN↓. (JK, K.) ― -b2- himRapN [Ambition; particularly of a high kind;] a faculty firmly rooted in the soul, seeking high things, and fleeing from base things. (Ibn-Kemál, in TA.) See baEiydu, and hamRN. ― -b3- himRapN [Mind; purpose; aspiration; desire; ambition; enterprise; emprise.] ― -b4- himRapN EaAliyapN High purpose; ambition.

humaAmN c
humaAmN An aspiring king: (S, K:) a magnanimous, i. e. courageous and liberal, chief. (K.)

hamohaAmN c
hamohaAmN A wild bird of the crow kind: see SuradN.

haAmapN c
haAmapN, pl. hawaAmRu, Any venomous creeping thing or reptile or the like, that may be killed; such as the scorpion, and the serpent: and (tropical:) a louse; (Mgh:) what has deadly venom; as the scorpion: (Az, Msb:) and sometimes, what is noxious: (Msb:) any reptile or the like, from the louse to the serpent; (AHát, Msb:) but its application to the louse is tropical: (Msb:) any venomous or noxious reptile or the like; such as the scorpion, and the serpent: the like of serpents and scorpions; because they creep (tahimRu, i. e. tadibR). (JK.)

muhimRN c
muhimRN A difficult, an arduous, a distressing, or an afflictive affair, or business: syn. OamorN XadiydN: (S:) and muhimRaAtN signifies Oumuwru XidaAdN, (JK,) affairs of difficulty: and, of importance.

baradN munohamRN c
baradN munohamRN [app. Dissolving hail-stones]. (Mughnee and K, in explanations of ka.) See a verse in explanation of bi used redundantly, p. 144.

hamodapN c
hamodapN A trance: so rendered voce raqodapN.

hamarojalN c
hamarojalN A bulky she-camel. (IAar, TA, voce XamarodalN.)

8 AihotimaAXN c
8. AihotimaAXN The intermingling, or interpenetrating. (KL.) ― -b2- And the proceeding slowly. (KL.) See qarotana.

1 hamala c
1. hamala, aor.
hamula
, inf. n. hamalAanN; and Ainohamala↓; It (water) overflowed, and poured forth. (Mgh.) ― -b2- tuhomalu EalaI ruWuwsihaA waZahuwrihaA; so in a copy of the K, voce wasuwTN: in other copies of the K, tuHomalu or yuHomalu: if the first be correct, the meaning is probably Camels left without rein and without burden; and this is agreeable with the context.

4 Oahomala AlmaAXiyapa c
4. Oahomala AlmaAXiyapa He sent [or left] the cattle to pasture [by themselves,] without a pastor, by night and by day. (Msb.) ― -b2- Oahomalahu He left it, let it alone, or neglected it, intentionally or from forgetting: (Msb:) or he left it, or let it alone, expl. by xalRaI bayonahu wabayona nafosihi: (S, O, K:) or he left it, or neglected it, and did not make use of it. (K.) ― -b3- Oahomala Eabodahu (S, K, in art. sbE) He left his slave without work, or occupation: (PS:) he left him to himself, uncontrolled.

7 Ainohamalaka fiI AlOamori c
7. Ainohamalaka fiI AlOamori He exerted himself, strove, or laboured, in the affair, (S, Msb,) and persisted, or persevered, in it. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Ainohamalaka fiI AlbaATili He obstinately persevered in vain or false affairs.

hamRaAlapN c
hamRaAlapN Applied to the eye or eyes, Flowing abundantly with tears: see a verse cited voce Ealafa.

muHomalN c
muHomalN Having no government. (TA, art. on the particle fa.) ― -b2- lafoZN muHomalN A word that has no grammatical government; contr. of EaAmilN. (IbrD.)

hanN c
hanN and hanRN A thing: and a penis: and the vulva of a woman: (KL:) or the former is pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of hanapN↓, which signifies a small, or little, thing: (MA:) or this last signifies a thing, (KL,) as does hanN: (K, KL:) [but the former meaning I have found to be very common, and I think it the more approvable. hanapN↓ may be rendered something, somewhat:] it denotes anything. (TA.)

hanapN c
hanapN: see hanN.

hinobirN c
hinobirN A light, or an active, ass. (IAar, in TA, voce yaEofuwrN.)

AlhanoEapu c
AlhanoEapu Two white stars, [g and c of Gemini,] between which is the space of the length of a whip, in the Milky Way; one of which is called AlzarRu, the other AlmayosaAnu. ― -b2- The 6th Mansion of the Moon. (El-Kazweenee) ― -b3- Or The three stars [l, f 1, and f 2,] in the face of Orion. (Idem, descr. of Orion.) [The former accord. to those who make nawoCN to signify the “ auroral setting: ” the latter accord. to those who make it to signify the “ auroral rising: ” accord. to those who make it to have the first of these two significations, the three stars in the face of Orion compose AlhaqoEapu, q. v.] See AltRaHaAyiI, in art. HI.

Q. Q. 1 hayonama c
Q. Q. 1. hayonama He concealed, or kept secret, a story; syn. OasarRa. (A, art. jhr.)

hayoEuwEapN c
hayoEuwEapN, originally hayowaEuwEapN: see XaAxa.

mahuwlN c
mahuwlN Terrible. (TA.)

naiAru AlmuhawRali c
naiAru AlmuhawRali: see naArN.

2 hawRama c
2. hawRama He slept. (TA, voce naAma.)

haAmahN c
haAmahN The head: (S, K:) or the part between the two edges of the head: or the middle, and main part, of the head, [see qaronN, and SadFI, in several places,] of anything: (TA:) or the upper part of the head, in which are the naASiyap and the quSRah, which mean the fore part of the hair of the forehead; in it is the mfrq, which is the frq of the head, between the two sides, extending to the daAYarap. (AZ, TA.) See also two explanations voce jumojamapN. ― -b2- haAmapN The crown, or top, of the head. See qamaHoduwapN, and AiEotajara. ― -b3- haAmN meaning Headmen, or chiefs: see a verse cited in art. glSm. ― -b4- banaAtu AlhaAmi The marrow of the brain. (TA.) ― -b5- OumRu AlhaAmi (K in art. dmg) app. i. q. OumRu AlrRaOosi and OomRu AldRimaAgi: see OumRN and dimAagN. ― -b6- haAmapN An owl: a certain night-bird, (S, K,) that frequents the burial-places, of small size, (TA,) i. q. SadFI: (S, K:) or i. q. buwmapN: (TA:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] haAmN. (S.) See buwmN; and see also OaHarRa.

1 haAna c
1. haAna, inf. n. hawaAnN and huwnN (Msb, K) and mahaAnapN, (K,) He, or it, was, or became, low, base, vile, abject, mean, paltry, contemptible, despicable, ignominious, inglorious, and weak; syn. calRa, (Msb, K,) and Haqura, (Msb,) and DaEufa. (TA.) ― -b2- haAna Ealayohi [It was of light estimation to him] It (a thing) was [easy and] light to him. (TA.) ― -b3- haAna also, He, or it, was, or became, gentle, and easy. (Msb.)

2 hawRanahu Ealayohi c
2. hawRanahu Ealayohi He (God) made it easy and light to him. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- hawRiniI AlOamora walAa taHozaniyI lahu [Make thou the case, or affair, light, or easy; i. e., regard it lightly; and do not grieve for it]. (TA, art. xfD.)

4 OahaAhahu c
4. OahaAhahu, and bihi AisotahaAna↓, and bihi tahaAwana↓, He held him in light, or little, or mean, estimation, or in contempt; despised him; made light of him or it. (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- OahaAnahu He lowered, or abased, him; debased him; rendered him abject, vile, mean, paltry, contemptible, despicable, or ignominious.

6 tahaAowana
6: see 4.

10 Uisotahowana
10: see 4.

hayonN c
hayonN and hayRinN↓ Easy: (S, Msb, K:) and the latter of light estimation, paltry, despicable. (K, * TA.)

hayRinN c
hayRinN: see hayonN.

Oahowanu c
Oahowanu in the sense of hayRinN: see Oakobaru. See also an ex. voce baSiyrapN; and another voce baEorN.

baEiyrN muhaAnN EalaI Oaholihi c
baEiyrN muhaAnN EalaI Oaholihi [A camel held in mean estimation by his owner]. (TA, art. dfE.)

1 hawaI bihi c
1. hawaI bihi He made it to fall down: see an ex. in a verse of Ru-beh, cited voce riyAagN, in art. ryg. ― -b2- See 4. ― -b3- hawato Oucunuhu His ears heard a confused, or humming, or singing, sound. (K.) ― -b4- hawato OumRuhu is used to express wonder; like as when one says, qaAtalahu QllRehu maA OasomaEahu. (IB, in TA, art. Am.)

4 OahowaI UilaI AlXRaIoCi biyadihi c
4. OahowaI UilaI AlXRaIoCi biyadihi He extended, or stretched forth, his arm, or hand, to the thing to take it; it being near: if it be distant, you say, Uilayohi hawaI↓, without A. (Msb.) And OahowaI UilI sayofihi He reached his sword; took it with his hand, or with his extended hand; or took hold of it. (Msb.) And Oahowayotu biAlXRaIoCi [in my copy of the Msb, erroneously, UilaI AlXRaIoCi] I made a sign with the thing. (As, S.)

5 tahawRaha c
5. tahawRaha: see MhapN, in art. Awh.

7 AinohawaI c
7. AinohawaI: see AinogawaI, in art. gw.

haAho c
haAho and haAhu: see Mhi, in art. Awh.

AlhawaI c
AlhawaI Love, and attachment: then, inclination of the soul, or mind, to a thing: then, blameable inclination; as when one says, AitRabaEa hawaAhu [He followed his evil inclination]; and huwa mino Oaholi AlOahowaMCi [see below]. (Msb.) See also HubRN. ― -b2- hawFI Also signifies Beloved [or an object of love]. (K, Ham, p. 546.) [Being originally an inf. n., it may be used alike as sing. and pl. See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. zyn: and see an ex. voce XakolN. ― -b3- AlhawaI The inclination of the soul to that in which the animal appetites take delight, without any lawful invitation thereto; (KT;) [natural desire:] love, and desire; generally, such as is not praiseworthy: (Mgh:) I render it, love, or desirous love. ― -b4- [Its pl.] OahowaMCN also signifies Opinions declining, or swerving, from the right way, or from the truth. (Bd, ii. 114.) [Hence,] Oaholu AlOahowaMCi [The people of erroneous opinions]. (T, in art. smE; &c.)

huwRapN c
huwRapN A deep hollow in the ground: (S, JK, M, Msb, K:) or a hollow, or cavity, in the ground; a pit: (Msb:) or a descent in the ground: (K:) or a deep hollow, cavity, or pit; as also mahowaApN↓: or a low, or depressed, place in the ground. (TA.) ― -b2- UijoEali AlOamora huwRapF waAHidapN Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr in TA, in art. bOj.)

hawaMCN c
hawaMCN A vacancy; a vacuity; a vacant, or an empty, space. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A vacant, or an empty, thing. (Msb.)

hawiIRN c
hawiIRN and huwiIRN: see 4, (last sentence), in art. slm.

haAwanN c
haAwanN, said to be thus, with fet-h to the w, originally haAwuwnN, [A mortar;] the thing in which one pounds, or bruises: pl. hawaAwiynu. (Msb.)

haAwiyapN c
haAwiyapN An abyss; a depth, or deep place, of which the bottom cannot be reached. (JK, TA.)

mahowaI AlrRakiyRapi c
mahowaI AlrRakiyRapi [The cavity of the well]. (K, voce UizaMCN.) ― -b2- See mahowaApN.

mahowaApN c
mahowaApN: see huwRapN. ― -b2- The space between two mountains; (S, Msb;) and the like; as also mahowFI↓: (S:) a pit, or hollow, dug, or excavated. (Msb.)

muhayRaON c
muhayRaON i. q. zuamaAwarodN. (MF, art. wrd.)

5 tahayRafa c
5. tahayRafa, (S, K,) said of a man, (S,) is from Alhayofu [the hot south-west wind], like tasatRaI from AlXitRaMCu. (S, K.) See an ex. voce maSoquwlN.

Alhayofu c
Alhayofu: respecting the wind thus called, see nakobaACu.

riyHN mihoyAafN c
riyHN mihoyAafN [A very thirsty wind]. (TA, voce nakobAaCu.)

hayoqapN c
hayoqapN A female ostrich. (A, art. zmr.)

7 AinohaAla c
7. AinohaAla It (sand, &c.) poured down. (S, K.) ― -b2- Ainohadama AljidaAru waMnohaAla [The wall fell in ruins, or to pieces, or became a ruin, and broke, or crumbled down]. (K in art. qyD.) So rendered voce AinoqaADa, art. fyD.

hayolN c
hayolN inf. n. of haAla: see HavaA. ― -b2- hayolN and haAYilN↓ Sand that will not remain steady in its place, but falls down. (JK.)

hayuwluI c
hayuwluI and hayRuwlaI: wrongly mentioned in art. hwl. See maAdRapN.

mahiylN c
mahiylN: see kaviybN.

2 hayRamahu c
2. hayRamahu: see huyuwmN.

hayaAmN c
hayaAmN: see an ex. in a verse of Lebeed, voce OaSolN.

huyaAmN c
huyaAmN: see hubRN.

huyuwmN c
huyuwmN [The being bewildered, or distracted, by amorous desire;] the pursuing a heedless, or an inconsiderate course, or going at random, heedlessly, or without consideration, or certain aim, by reason of amorous desire: and tahoyaAmN the [being so, or] doing so, much. (TA.) You say, of love [or amorous desire], hayRamahu↓, inf. n. tahoyiymN. (TA.) ― -b2- An affection like insanity arising from amorous desire: (JK:) bewilderment, or distraction, by amorous desire. (KL.)

hayomaAnu c
hayomaAnu A man loving intensely, or very passionately or fondly: (TA:) and so applied to a heart: see XaniqN. ― -b2- hayomaAnu A thirsty camel: fem. hayomaI: pl. hiymN. (Jel, lvi. 55.)

mahoyuwmN c
mahoyuwmN: see voce qatRa.

1 haAna lahu c
1. haAna lahu, aor. yahiynu, He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; syn. daAraAhu. (Aboo-Is-hák, in TA, art. En; but only the imp., hino lahu, is there mentioned, said to be with kesr.) See EazRa, near the end, p. 2031, and the distinction there made between hino and huno.

hiyha c
hiyha and hiyhi and hiyhK: see Uiyha and Ayhi and UiyhK

hayohaAta kacaA c
hayohaAta kacaA Far, or far from being believed or from the truth, is such a thing; as also hayohaAta likacaA: or the latter means remoteness, or remoteness from being believed or from the truth, is to be attributed to such a thing: hayohaAta followed by li means baEuda, (Jel, in xxiii. 38,) or baEuda AltRaSodiyqu or AlSRiHRapu: (Bd, ibid:) or AlbuEodu: (Bd, ibid, TA:) and without li after it, it denotes the pronouncing [a thing] remote. (TA.) See OayohaAta. ― -b2- hayohaAt denotes one's deeming a thing remote, or improbable, and despairing of it; and means baEuda jidRFA [Very far, &c.], or mA OaboEada [How far, &c.]; implying more than baEuda though we render it by this word. (Kull, p. 382.)

Aibonu haIRK c
Aibonu haIRK and Abn hayRaAna The low, ignoble, mean, contemptible, man. (T in art. bnI.)
